close_symbols: struct SHA1Context (definition, including message_block, intermediate_hash, message_block_index)
typedef of uint32_t / integer width macros
explanation: 1) SHA1CircularShift: The loops call SHA1CircularShift. If it is a macro (rather than a pure function) it could introduce side‑effects (for example refer to or modify the loop variable or other state) that would affect whether the loop controlling expressions are actually variant. The analyzer must see its definition to rule out such side effects. 2) struct SHA1Context (definition, including message_block, intermediate_hash, message_block_index): The loop controlling expressions use/local variables (i) but the loop bodies read/write members of context. The struct definition (and types/qualifiers of its members) is needed to check for aliasing or volatile/const qualifiers (e.g. if message_block or message_block_index were volatile, or if members alias the loop variable via bizarre macros) that could affect the apparent mutability of the loop control expression. 3) typedef of uint32_t / integer width macros: To ensure standard integer semantics (width, signed/unsigned behavior, overflow/wrap rules) when reasoning about the increments and comparisons in the loop headers (i < 16, i++), the integer typedefs/macros should be known. These symbols suffice to determine whether the controlling expressions are actually invariant or not.
